meanings.definition: Rise in rebellion against an authority or government.
meanings.sent1: The citizens decided to revolt against the unfair ruler.
meanings.sent2: The people may revolt if they are treated unfairly for too long.
meanings.sent3: The idea of having to eat broccoli every day made the child revolt.
meanings.sent4: The students' revolt against the strict dress code was swift and powerful.
meanings.sent5: The image of the hero leading the revolt against the evil king was inspiring.

meanings.definition: Cause to feel disgust or shock.
meanings.sent1: The horrible smell from the garbage bin can revolt anyone passing by.
meanings.sent2: The gruesome scene in the movie may revolt some viewers.
meanings.sent3: The idea of eating bugs might revolt some people, but others find it normal.
meanings.sent4: The graphic images in the documentary revolted the audience and left them speechless.
meanings.sent5: The taste of the strange dish revolted her taste buds, and she quickly spat it out.

meanings.definition: A violent uprising against an authority or government.
meanings.sent1: The revolt led to chaos in the city as the rebels clashed with the army.
meanings.sent2: The history books are filled with stories of revolt against oppressive regimes.
meanings.sent3: The comedy show portrayed a hilarious version of a kitchen utensil revolt.
meanings.sent4: The revolt of the machines in the movie was a chilling reminder of the power of technology.
meanings.sent5: The painting depicted a vivid scene of a peasant revolt against the nobles.
